Award.AwardTitle: Implantable biosensors for real-time in vivo interrogation of biological phenomena

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Sayler
1159344

This research effort is focused on the merging of light-emitting (bioluminescent) human cell lines with integrated circuit microluminometers to create miniaturized, implantable biosensing interfaces for internal monitoring of animal physiology. Conventional imaging technology relies on external cameras to penetrate and identify light-emitting cellular signatures embedded within small animal subjects. Unfortunately, due to absorption, attenuation, and scattering, even the most sensitive ultracooled cameras are unable to detect light signals beyond depths of a few centimeters in living tissue. Without major advances in imaging hardware sensitivity and/or light signal emission strength of engineered implanted cells, bioimaging applications that promise real-time, noninvasive visualization of health status in small animals may never achieve the transformational leap towards imaging, tracking, and diagnosing diseases in larger animals (i.e., humans). It is hypothesized that it may be more feasible and practical to image internally rather than externally, and that the bioengineering of an implantable optical chip capable of detecting light from engineered human cells tuned to human disease states may be a solution for effective whole-body human imaging. The intellectual merit of this research is a transformative new imaging technology that brings us closer to biosensing strategies evolved towards autonomous sense-and-respond human biotherapies where disease states are automatically recognized and treated, the outcome of which permits real-time and remote patient to doctor relationships and transformations in personalized medicine and disease care management at greatly reduced costs. Broader impacts include postdoctoral training and integration of undergraduate students within the research project, multidisciplinary collaborations between the life sciences and engineering disciplines, broad dissemination of research results, and outreach efforts centered on K-12 Science, Technology, Engineering & Mathematics (STEM) initiatives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to merge human cells with integrated circuits to create living sensors capable of detecting disease and to provide improved screening technologies for ensuring the safety and efficacy of drugs used to treat disease. The human cells were designed to emit bioluminescent light when exposed to specific chemicals or disease signatures. The integrated circuit chip was designed to detect the bioluminescent light being produced from the cells. By pairing the two together, an all-in-one living sensor could be realized for advancing our knowledge of how to better monitor human disease and how to create better drugs for treating and managing human disease. With its tiny 1.5 x 1.5 mm footprint, the biochip sensor may potentially be implantable within the human body to continuously monitor for disease and pre-alert to disease conditions if they are detected. For example, certain signatures related to cancer may be detectable very early if sensors were constantly monitoring the internal physiological state of a patient, and a pre-alert signal could be transmitted to a watch or cell phone to communicate declining health status. Outside of the human body, such a biochip device could be layered with various human cells and tissue types to enable a newly discovered drug to be tested specific to each patient, in what is referred to as personalized medicine, to ensure that each drug a patient receives is highly effective at treating the disease at hand while exhibiting as few harmful side-effects as possible. Such a device would additionally lessen our reliance on animals for testing drug safety and efficacy. Furthermore, such a device would have application potential beyond the biomedical disciplines to also include environmental biomonitoring to alert for harmful chemical contaminants in water supplies, in the air, or in food.

This research project included a postdoctoral scientist and directly challenged 18 undergraduate students and 10 high school students. Four undergraduate students achieved co-authorship on articles published in the scientific literature. All student participants were tasked with communicating the outcomes of their research to the general public, which included attendance at local science fairs and outreach to local grade schools and high schools. Of particular value to the State of Tennessee were outreach efforts targeting rural Appalachian school districts where these students used their research to stimulate interest in the science and technology disciplines. As well, these students participated in workshops where they taught scientific techniques to high school teachers from across the State of Tennessee and provided lesson plans for the teachers to use within their classrooms.
